{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3408599,"name":"Matthew Milunic","username":"mathum","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/8baadc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-15T22:52:46.216Z","cooked":"

This is a little project I’ve been working on to very simply get an easy to setup system that allows running WPILib projects that interact with the GPIO on a RaspberryPi. This should work for any RaspberryPi that can connect to the same network as the computer that has the code on it (even through a spare old robot radio for example).

GitHub

GitHub - mmilunicmobile/RoboPiLink: A base WPILib project that can interface...

A base WPILib project that can interface with any Raspberry Pi over a network connection! - mmilunicmobile/RoboPiLink

Ideally this is a good way to train students with WPILib using old RaspberryPi’s that aren’t being used. Its still in a bit of a prototype stage, let me know if you have any ideas for improvements or concerns! Thanks! (Also feel free to leave a pull request or something if you’re so inclined.)

This is a great idea! I hope it gets the attention it deserves. To make installation easier for users, consider making a github release with the source code and a script to install missing libraries, update to latest versions, and run the watchdog script or other safety checks. Gl on development and happy coding!

Thank you for the recommendation! I’m working on a script right now that does the setup process. It’s very simple to use and also sets the watchdog and pigpiod as a daemon so you only have to start it once, even between restarts. My guess is it’ll be done pretty soon as it’s functional, i just want to add docs for it.

RoboPiLink v0.2.0 Release!

This version comes with an installation script that should make setup significantly simpler. Additionally, the internals were switched from using a background Python process to using diozero instead, making it much more stable.

GitHub

Release RoboPiLink v0.2.0 · mmilunicmobile/RoboPiLink

This release heavily changes the workings of the program internally, transitioning from using a background interactive Python process (which was incredibly sketchy) to using diozero. Additionally, ...

Would it be easier to look at using the WebSocket protocol (implemented with the Romis)? Then you have the full support of WpiLib for the PC code driving it, and you would just have to implement the code on the Pi to listen to the websocket.

github.com

wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/main/simulation/halsim_ws_core/doc/hardware_ws_api.md

# Robot Hardware Interface WebSockets API Specification

- [Summary](#summary)
- [Motivation](#motivation)
- [References](#references)
- [Design](#design)
  - [WebSockets Protocol Configuration](#websockets-protocol-configuration)
  - [Text Data Frames](#text-data-frames)
  - [Robot Program Behavior](#robot-program-behavior)
  - [Hardware Behavior](#hardware-behavior)
  - [Hardware Messages](#hardware-messages)
  - [CAN Messages](#can-messages)
  - [RoboRIO Messages](#roborio-messages)
  - [Other Device Messages ("SimDevice")](#other-device-messages-simdevice)

## Summary

A WebSockets API for transmitting robot hardware interface state over a network.  In typical use, one end of the connection is a robot program running in a desktop environment, and the other end of the connection is either a simulation engine, physical robot, or simulation dashboard GUI.

## Motivation

Personally, I felt that the WebSocket protocol was a bit confusing (aka I have skill issues) and also using diozero gives you more direct control over the Pis pins. Additionally, using diozero means that technically, support for any other platform diozero supports is a very simple addition. I do see the disadvantage of using something that would only work with Java, but at the same time, almost everyone uses Java to program their robot. Currently, it does work and so I don’t feel much motivation to switch over to the WebSocket protocol, but thats just my opinion.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-07-25T17:45:58.182Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":47.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468715,"topic_slug":"introducing-robopilink-easily-run-wpilib-programs-on-raspberrypis","display_username":"Matthew Milunic","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-blog-technology-updates-past-present-future-and-beyond-apriltags-and-new-radio/440931/9","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"[FRC Blog] Technology Updates: Past, Present, Future, and Beyond - AprilTags and New Radio","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":1737,"username":"Steven_Carmain","name":"Steven Carmain","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f07891/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Bug Writer"},"post_url":"/t/introducing-robopilink-easily-run-wpilib-programs-on-raspberrypis/468715/8","custom_user_title":"Lead Bug Writer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3411287,"name":"Steven Carmain","username":"Steven_Carmain","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f07891/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-26T00:15:34.993Z","cooked":"

Maybe I missed how this works. If you are running the code directly on the PI, then ignore me and you did it right.

I took a glance through your code and thought it was running on the PC. It looks like you are running native on the PI instead.

Most the rest of the robots I was used to (Romi/XRP) are only physical replicators of what the code does. The code runs on the PC, decides what the motor command does, and then transmits it wirelessly to the robot. That is what the WebSocket part does (or a custom binary format for XRP), so you can use the higher power laptop to do the heavy computational work, and the device can be commodity hardware.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-07-26T21:10:11.680Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":74,"readers_count":73,"score":14.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468715,"topic_slug":"introducing-robopilink-easily-run-wpilib-programs-on-raspberrypis","display_username":"Kevin Vo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59671,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/introducing-robopilink-easily-run-wpilib-programs-on-raspberrypis/468715/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3420771,"name":"Matthew Milunic","username":"mathum","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/8baadc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-05T02:09:27.098Z","cooked":"

The code is running directly on the PC in this case, but instead of using a WebSocket to communicate instructions to the RaspberryPi, it uses pigpio through the diozero Java library. The benefit is that pigpio already exists (so I don’t have to write the communications part) and its more well executed than anything I could ever write. Additionally, diozero technically supports more than just RaspberryPi’s, so with very minor tweaks you could modify this code to run with a different device. In this case all that runs on the Pi is the pigpiod daemon and the watchdog which makes sure the pi doesn’t leave pins on. PS my bad for the long response time, I kinda got distracted with like marching band and school and stuff.
